So first iteration, a[i] is 1>0, so check if b[i] (2) < e (0, since e is initialized to 0). 2 < 0 is false, so f remains. Then w becomes 1, e becomes 2. Next iteration, a[i] is 2>1: check if b[i] 1 < e (2) → yes. So f is set to true. Then w becomes 2, e becomes 1. So overall, f is true, output "Happy Alex".

children.text: Thus, the Fortran code should replicate this logic. Now, let's write the code.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
The Fortran code would look like:

program codeforces_456_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, i, temp, q, w, e
    integer, allocatable :: a(:), b(:)
    logical :: f

    read *, n
    allocate(a(n), b(n)) do i = 1, n
        read *, a(i), b(i)
    end do

    temp = 0
    q = 0
    w = 0
    e = 0
    f = .false. do i = 1, n
        if (temp < a(i)) then
            if (q > b(i)) then
                f = .true.
            end if
            q = b(i)
            temp = a(i)
        end if

        if (temp > a(i)) then
            if (q < b(i)) then
                f = .true.
            end if
            q = b(i)
            temp = a(i)
        end if

        if (a(i) > w) then
            if (b(i) < e) then
                f = .true. end if
            w = a(i)
            e = b(i)
        end if

        if (a(i) < w) then
            if (b(i) > e) then
                f = .true. end
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
if
        end if
    end do

    if (f) then
        print *, "Happy Alex"
    else
        print *, "Poor Alex"
    end if

    deallocate(a, b)
end program codeforces_456_A

Wait, but in Fortran, the syntax requires that the parentheses are properly placed, and lines can't have certain syntax.

So first iteration, a[i] is 1>0, so check if b[i] (2) < e (0, since e is initialized to 0). 2 < 0 is false, so f remains. Then w becomes 1, e becomes 2. Next iteration, a[i] is 2>1: check if b[i] 1 < e (2) → yes. So f is set to true. Then w becomes 2, e becomes 1.

So overall, f is true, output "Happy Alex".

Thus, the Fortran code should replicate this logic.

Now, let's write the code.

The Fortran code would look like:

program codeforces_456_A
    implicit none
    integer :: n, i, temp, q, w, e
    integer, allocatable :: a(:), b(:)
    logical :: f

    read *, n
    allocate(a(n), b(n))
    do i = 1, n
        read *, a(i), b(i)
    end do

    temp = 0
    q = 0
    w = 0
    e = 0
    f = .false.

    do i = 1, n
        if (temp < a(i)) then
            if (q > b(i)) then
                f = .true.
            end if
            q = b(i)
            temp = a(i)
        end if

        if (temp > a(i)) then
            if (q < b(i)) then
                f = .true.
            end if
            q = b(i)
            temp = a(i)
        end if

        if (a(i) > w) then
            if (b(i) < e) then
                f = .true.
            end if
            w = a(i)
            e = b(i)
        end if

        if (a(i) < w) then
            if (b(i) > e) then
                f = .true.
            end if
        end if
    end do

    if (f) then
        print *, "Happy Alex"
    else
        print *, "Poor Alex"
    end if

    deallocate(a, b)
end program codeforces_456_A

Wait, but in Fortran, the syntax requires that the parentheses are properly placed, and lines can't have certain syntax. Also, in the allocate statement, I wrote b(n)), which is a typo. Should be b(n).

Wait, the code has:

allocate(a(n), b(n))

But in Fortran, the commas are correct. allocate(a(n), b(n)) is okay.

Other possible issues: in the loop, when comparing temp < a(i), etc. Also, Fortran is case-insensitive, but variable names are in lower case here.
